prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Dust continuum observation
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to detect the dust continuum at 350GHz for star-forming galaxies at z>2. This proposal is related to our cycle-1 proposal (2012.1.00245.S), which is similar high-resolution observations of dust continuum. The large sample is needed to confirm our onsiderable result (whether dusty star formation is occurring in a galaxy center).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: Our targets are 14 star-forming galaxies at z>2. The feasibility is carefully estimated from the existing MIPS 24μm and AzTEC 1.1mm data. The targets are all detected in MIPS 24um images (S24um > 100 uJy), suggesting that they are dusty galaxies with a total infrared luminosity of LIR > 1e12 Lsun (the calibration by Wuyts et al. 2008). Moreover, the stacking analysis of AzTEC 1.1 mm (270GHz) images shows the averaged flux of S270GHz= 1.22+-0.21 mJy (6sigma) for these MIPS-detected targets. In the stacking analysis, objects near bright submm sources (within 30 arcsec) were excluded to avoid contaminations. From the 1.1 mm flux density, we estimated 350 GHz flux density by using a dust SED model of a gray-body radiation with assuming beta=1.5 and Tdust = 35 K (Dunne et al. 2000). The expected flux density at 350GHz is S350GHz ~ 2.4 mJy. The estimated total infrared luminosity is LIR=1.4e12 which is consistent with the MIPS-based luminosity. Even if we change the assumed dust temperature over the range of Tdust = 25 − 45 K, the flux density at 350GHz is almost unchanged. Based on the official ALMA sensitivity calculator, we can reach to the limiting flux density of 25sigma=2.4mJy with 4.5 min integration over the full bandwidth (7.5 GHz) in Band-7 (350GHz).
Imaging and Configuration: The requested angular resolution, 0.16", is accomplished by the C34-6 configuration at Band-7. The size of galaxies (~1") is far smaller than the maximum recoverable scale of 2.6" in this configuration. Our targets consists two or three clumps with kpc size (0.1-0.2") per galaxy (Figure 1 in SJ). The flux of galaxies are expected to be dominated by these clumps from the HST morphologies. Even if the flux is divided into four components evenly, 5sigma detection is still expected. In fact, the image simulation with CASA produces a good map in the C34-6 configuration (Figure 4).
Correlater setup: We aim to observe continuum at 350GHz. Therefore, we request TDM.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to conduct 0¥arcsec.16 resolution dust continuum (350GHz) imagings of 14 star-forming galaxies at z>2 which has been identified by narrow-band surveys with Subaru Telescope in SXDF-CANDELS field. The targets are very suitable for ALMA cycle-2 capabilities because the feasibility is carefully estimated from their MIPS 24um and AzTEC 1.1mm data. Their rest-frame UV/optical images have already been obtained by WFC3/ACS on HST.
ALMA is the only instrument which can provide us with such high-resolution submm maps.
Combining the rest-frame far-infrared images by ALMA with the rest-frame UV images by HST, we aim to resolve the internal distribution of star formation activities including both dust obscured and unobscured ones and identify the mode of star formation such as ``burstiness'' and ``dustiness'' in each resolved region or clump for the first time. Our question is, ``where are new stars being formed within high-redshift galaxies?''. This could be closely related to formation of bulges and disks. With the extensive high-resolution data-set, we will confirm the epoch of bulge formation and address this issue.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00245.S,`` Spatially Resolved Mode of Star Formation in Halpha emitters at z>2'' by Ken-ichi Tadaki
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
